original: Contemporary fungi exhibit similarities to their ancestors, which date back over a million years. Notably, a mosquito preserved in Dominican amber was discovered with various types of parasitic fungi growing on its external cuticle. These fungi resemble modern-day members of the class Trichomycetes, which are commonly found inhabiting the guts of insects. However, a key distinction is that the ancient fungi were located on the exterior
sampled: Contemporary fungi exhibit similarities to their ancestors, which date previously than a million years. Notably, a mosquito preserved in Dominican amber was examined with various types of parasitic fungi expanding on its external cuticle. These fungi resemble modern-day members among the classification Trichomycetes, which are systematically found inhabiting the guts of insects. However, an key variety is that the ancient fungi were located on the exterior
